timeline.bodyText:
(just thinking aloud, no action needed)
This is basically saying that all classes within the org.optaplanner namespace aren't exploitable.
That included org.optaplanner.examples, which did has this code in the dinner party example:
  <customPhase>
    <customPhaseCommandClass>org.optaplanner.examples.dinnerparty.solver.solution.initializer.DinnerPartySolutionInitializer</customPhaseCommandClass>
  </customPhase>

That has test coverage, so all is well with JAXB, I presume?
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText:
JAXB accepts classes you specifically define when creating the JAXBContext. These are eligible to act as root elements. Then, it accepts any type it has to serialize in the object graph under these root element types.
This particular example is not about DinnerPartySolutionInitializer, though. The type to be (de)serialized here is Class.
replies.author: rsynek

timeline.bodyText:
(code style, very soft): the first letter after "// " should be a capital, so "// Required ...", even if it's not a sentance
Basically same principles as javadocs.
((If it's a sentence (subject + verb + ...), it must end with a ".", otherwise it shouldn't. This is already correct.))

timeline.bodyText:
(thinking aloud, feel free to ignore)
This was there to avoid xstream ID references in the html report that shows the source XML.
Basically, the source XML must be copyable and not introduce any changes from having been parsed and unparsed, except for inheriting the inheritedSolver of the benchmark xml.
So no id's add that weren't there, no null fields becoming defaulted fields etc.
I presume this is all fine, as IIRC we do have a test that covers it.
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText:
